articles.title: June '79
articles.summary: This document outlines a series of astronomical events and meetings scheduled for June and July 1979, primarily for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA). Key activities include general meetings with board elections and slide shows, various indoor and outdoor star parties, and larger events like the Riverside Telescope Makers' Conference and the ASP Summer Meeting. It also notes the 10th anniversary of the Moon landing and an annual installation picnic.

articles.title: Observations
articles.summary: This article, titled "Observations," announces the bulletin's new name, discusses membership renewals, and details upcoming club events like a July picnic and the ASP Summer Meeting which includes an astrophotography workshop. It also provides a detailed report on a successful but challenging star party at Fremont Peak, where several members completed Messier Club qualifications despite fog and dewing issues. The editor reflects on the 10th anniversary of the moon landing and explains the bulletin's early release due to an upcoming conference.

articles.title: Comet Comments
articles.summary: This article provides an update on comet activity, noting no recent discoveries but highlighting Comet Meier, which is currently visible in the morning sky. It details observing information for Comet Meier, including its coordinates and magnitude as it leaves the solar system. The text also briefly explains the nature of comet nuclei and the formation of comet trails, referencing past notable comets.

articles.title: Graze Notes
articles.summary: An attempt to observe a lunar graze was thwarted by clouds and rain, leading to a humorous account of the expedition. The article also discusses the impending re-entry of Skylab with satirical speculation and reports on a May 12th indoor star party where members collaboratively tackled an impromptu car transmission repair before engaging in astronomy-related activities and discussions.

articles.title: Rattley Rattles
articles.summary: This President's message, titled "Rattley Rattles," highlights the importance of the upcoming June elections for the club's Board of Directors, urging members to participate and vote wisely. It addresses the challenges of managing a growing club and solicits member input on their interests and expectations to better plan future events and club direction. The message also details the critical responsibilities of board members in governing the club, setting policy, and managing its operations.

articles.title: Rattley Rattles continued . . .
articles.summary: The article announces an upcoming general meeting that will feature an open forum for members to discuss club matters and provide feedback through a questionnaire, aiming to improve club governance and engagement. Members are encouraged to actively participate to ensure the club reflects their wishes, especially since a previous survey in 1976 received minimal response. The meeting will also include a 'slide night' for members to share astronomical slides, followed by a showing of the President's Astronomy Day slide show for public outreach, seeking member comments for its improvement.

articles.title: Across
articles.summary: This document presents a list of "Across" clues from a crossword puzzle. The clues cover a range of topics, predominantly featuring astronomical terms, scientific concepts, and general knowledge, with a strong emphasis on celestial bodies, discoveries, and related figures.

articles.title: Down
articles.summary: This document, titled "Down," comprises a list of numbered cryptic clues, characteristic of a crossword puzzle's "down" section. The clues predominantly feature astronomical themes, referencing celestial objects like stars, nebulas, and planets, as well as historical figures in astronomy and specific scientific terminology.

articles.title: Answers to Sky Word #2
articles.summary: This document provides the solutions to 'Sky Word #2,' presenting a completed crossword puzzle grid. It serves as an answer key for the astronomy-themed word puzzle.

articles.title: HELP!!!
articles.summary: An urgent call to action for club members to participate in a special photo session for the club's new brochure. The aim is to photograph as many members as possible with their instruments in front of the Rosicrucian Museum. The session is scheduled for June 2nd at 6:30 PM, prior to the general meeting, and members are asked to bring their instruments or simply attend.

articles.title: AVAILABLE PUBLICATIONS
articles.summary: The club offers a continuing list of publications from Sky Publishing at significant discounts, ranging from 10% to 45%. Members interested in ordering these discounted items should contact the club treasurer, Bob Fingerhut, at 263-4455.

articles.title: HANS VEHRENBERG'S PUBLICATIONS
articles.summary: The article lists various astronomical publications by Hans Vehrenberg, including several star atlases and handbooks, along with their prices. The editor advocates for Vehrenberg to be considered for the G. Bruce Blair award, citing his significant contributions to amateur astronomy. Additionally, there's an announcement regarding an upcoming cutoff date for ordering astronomy-themed T-shirts.

articles.title: As our charter beach Baron climbs into the clouds above
articles.summary: A group of observers embarked on an challenging aerial expedition in a private plane to view a total solar eclipse, battling persistent clouds by climbing to a record-setting altitude of 23,500 feet. Despite technical difficulties and physical discomfort, they successfully witnessed the stunning totality, observing the corona and protuberances, creating an incredibly beautiful and unforgettable experience. The arduous journey resulted in new altitude records for the pilot and plane, leaving participants with profound and lasting memories.

articles.title: Coffee, Tea, or Eclipse....?
articles.summary: On February 26, a group of Bay Area astronomy club members embarked on a challenging expedition from Walla Walla, Washington, to observe a solar eclipse. Despite encountering numerous obstacles, including rain, forgotten team members, airplane troubles, and navigation issues, they ultimately found a clear spot near Grass Valley, Oregon. Although they couldn't see full totality, they witnessed Baily's Beads and experienced the profound darkness of the eclipse's shadow, making the arduous trip a memorable success.

articles.title: Partial Eclipse
articles.summary: On February 26, 1979, two distinct groups undertook aerial observations of a solar eclipse. One group successfully viewed a 52% partial eclipse from a Cessna 172 above San Jose, California, avoiding ground-level rain. Simultaneously, another group chartered a twin-engine jet to fly over Washington state, aiming to observe the total solar eclipse and conduct specific scientific experiments like studying shadow bands, despite the challenges of an unstable platform.

articles.title: The Eclipse
articles.summary: This article details a successful airborne observation of a total solar eclipse from a Pan Jet Falcon at 10.7 km altitude. It highlights the unique challenges of airborne astronomy, including precise navigation calculations, aircraft stability for instruments, and last-minute logistical changes. Despite these hurdles, the team achieved optimal viewing, experiencing over three minutes of spectacular totality with a clear, dark sky and brilliant corona, superior to ground-based observations.

articles.title: Handles
articles.summary: This document lists CB radio handles for members and bulletin subscribers of a club, compiled due to popular demand. It includes individual handles, group handles for specific activities like grazes and occultations, and notes the frequented CB channels (14 and 20) for club communications and star parties. The author encourages members to report any omissions for future amendments.

articles.title: Picnic Reservation Form
articles.summary: This document is a picnic reservation form, instructing attendees to send money and reservations to Bobby Pingerhut in Milpitas, CA. It allows participants to order steak dinners, hot dog dinners, and extra steaks or hot dogs, with spaces to calculate the total amount enclosed.
